Terry Malloy.Action: Returns Joey Doyle's lost racing pigeon and offers to bring it to his loft.
Acts tensely and tries to avoid drawing attention, then releases the pigeon unexpectedly.
Subdues the live racing pigeon expertly, recognizing the band and making the connection to Joey's pigeon.
Uses a gesture that might have been interpreted as drawing a gun but instead reveals the racing pigeon, showing a controlled and deliberate action.
Appears tense and uneasy, suggesting internal conflict and hesitation about his actions.
Releases the pigeon inexplicably instead of delivering it to Joey, which could be viewed as lacking clear purpose or follow-through.
Dismisses Mutt Murphy's request for money and coffee brusquely ('Go on, beat it!').
Takes an anxious glance back toward the tenement after dismissing Mutt.
Releases the pigeon and watches its flight, seemingly anxious about the effect of his action.
Dismisses the begging Mutt Murphy brusquely and with irritation.
Avoids direct confrontation by not responding to Joey's calls on the rooftop, allowing two men to approach Joey stealthily.
Reports to Charley about Joey being trapped on the roof without showing hesitation or sympathy.
Replies resentfully to Charley’s remark, indicating internal conflict or discomfort.
Informs Charley accurately and promptly about the situation on the roof, showing awareness of ongoing events.
Appears tense and resentful when reporting to Charley, indicating possible emotional conflict affecting objective decision-making.
Shows horror and concern at Joey's fall and questions charitably about Joey's character ('He wasn't a bad little fella')
Struggles not to be carried away by the crowd, indicating some self-control and reluctance to rush,
Works his way calmly toward Charley and Truck instead of running with the crowd, showing control over his impulses.
Catches the meaning of Truck's wink and realizes the gravity of the situation, indicating perceptiveness.
Struggles not to be carried along with the excited crowd, maintaining composure.
Misunderstands the severity of Joey's situation, believing the worst would only be rough treatment rather than fatal consequences.
Looks at Truck, stricken, but does not take immediate action or respond confidently.
Appears bewildered when invited to have a drink; hesitates before responding.
Watches longshoremen hurrying past him without moving or engaging.
Shakes his head and walks away from the bar despite invitations to join and drink
Sits brooding alone at the bar, preoccupied and disturbed
Shakes his head and leaves the main bar area despite others calling to him, showing awareness and reflective behavior.
Sits at the bar brooding, appearing preoccupied and disturbed, not engaging actively with others around him.
Comes over reluctantly when called but accepts money and tries to count it.
Stops counting and proudly taps his nose, signaling confidence.
Reacts hot-tempered and starts to attack Big Mac after being teased.
Takes money from Johnny sulkily and tries to count the bills though clearly unskilled, loses count and shows difficulty with arithmetic.
Proudly claims 'not a dent' and 'perfect' after winning a fight, showing confidence in his physical abilities.
Shows regret and deference when reprimanded by Johnny, acknowledging his mistake sincerely ('I know, Johnny, I know...')
Shows restraint when Johnny speaks harshly and with authority, indicating he understands his position and listens respectfully.
Starts to attack Big Mac hot-temperedly, showing impulsiveness rather than measured skill in handling conflict.
Remains uncomfortably silent when pressured by Johnny and others about the corrupt deal, showing hesitation and discomfort.
Accepts money from Johnny with a smile, despite the tense and exploitative situation.
Terry is uncomfortably silent when Johnny confronts him about being left out of the deal and only responds with weak justification.
Johnny impulsively hands Terry money and a job, indicating Terry's low status and dependence rather than independent competence.
Answers ship whistle irritably but playfully warns about spilling water to protect birds from cold.
Exchanges a friendly salute with Jimmy, showing camaraderie.
Looks around disturbed by men's muttering and defensive when confronted with gossip about himself.
Answers the ship whistle irritably and acknowledges Jimmy's salute with the same gesture while appearing disturbed, indicating some awareness and responsiveness to the situation.
Looks around trying to hear what the men are muttering behind him, showing some attentiveness but also uncertainty or unease.
Responds defensively to Chick's insinuation by questioning who told him that, showing some awareness but insecurity or lack of control over the gossip.
Hotly tells Jackie 'that's enough' after his mock praise, showing some assertiveness but perhaps a lack of calm confidence.
Responds suspiciously and impatiently to the investigators, refuses to cooperate.
Defensive but does not escalate confrontation physically despite provocation.
Refuses to cooperate with authorities and tells them to get lost.
Swaggers and jokes with friends to show defiance.
Responds to friends' rough affection positively, showing camaraderie.
Refuses to cooperate or share information with the officers, claiming ignorance and telling them to get lost.
Swaggers confidently in front of friends, boasting that he nearly fought the officers despite the consequences.
Steps forward promptly when called at the longshoremen's lineup, indicating willingness to engage and take responsibility.
Waits silently and hopefully among other men rather than actively negotiating or asserting himself to secure work.
Blocks Pop off with his leg and hands a tab to a crony instead of Pop during a violent scramble.
Blocks Pop off with his leg while grabbing a tab and handing it to a crony.
Engages in a chaotic fight for the tabs but focuses on helping a crony rather than securing one decisively for himself.
Acknowledges Edie's claim to the tab and returns it to her despite initial teasing and bravado.
Engages in light-hearted banter with Jackie and shows forced bravado, masking guilt.
Lies comfortably reading a comic book instead of working, gives a dismissive answer to Charley.
Lying comfortably on coffee bags reading a comic book instead of actively working or paying attention.
Counts the bags to justify not working continuously, indicating some basic responsibility and awareness of his tasks.
Is nominated by Charley to gather intelligence on a meeting, suggesting others see him as capable of handling sensitive tasks.
Expresses hesitation and discomfort about taking on the task of giving a rundown on the players, feeling like a stool pigeon.
Eventually agrees to join the group in the church despite initial reluctance, showing some willingness to engage.
Speaks out about the need to stop mob violence and get justice for Joey Doyle.
Sets his jaw stubbornly and reacts angrily when mob-related name is brought up.
Remains tight-lipped and does not answer questions about Joey Doyle's murder.
Presents a clear, simple argument about breaking the mob's hold and calls for justice, showing moral clarity and some leadership potential.
Looks around at the silent crowd, attempts to start a conversation but hesitates to openly accuse or lead effectively.
Sets his jaw stubbornly but remains tight-lipped when questioned about Joey Doyle’s murder, showing reluctance to speak out fully or provide useful information.
Turns around angrily to defend Charley’s name, indicating emotional reactivity and poor strategic judgment in a delicate situation.
Turns around angrily and insolently tells Nolan to ask Charley the Gent himself.
Laughs scornfully at Nolan's vague threat about 'one of these days.'
Turns around angrily and insolently dismisses Nolan's suggestion to ask Charley the Gent for help, laughing scornfully at the idea.
Pulls Edie back from danger and quickly leads her to a safer exit despite her surprise.
Looks at Edie and quickly assesses the room for other exits, then leads Edie to safety despite her surprise.
Pulls Edie along quickly to avoid danger, hides her in the shadows to evade pursuing goons, and then leads her safely away down an alley, checking carefully for safety before proceeding.
Responds with simple, somewhat evasive answer when asked which side he is on ("I'm with Terry"), reflecting uncertainty or lack of clear stance.
Nervously reaches into his pocket and reluctantly gives money to Mutt, showing unease and lack of confidence.
Responds evasively when Edie asks about Joey, avoiding direct answers and lacking straightforwardness.
Attempts to reassure Edie by telling her not to be afraid, indicating some social awareness and effort to engage positively.
Engages in light, confident banter with Edie, recalling past memories and expressing admiration for intellect.
Jokes awkwardly about Edie’s past appearance but recovers with humor and charm.
Appears unsure why Edie keeps physical distance, fails to notice or address it directly.
Foxes the Sisters who tried to beat an education into him, demonstrating street-smart cleverness.
Plays imaginary violin and makes playful, slightly evasive comments, showing wit and lightheartedness.
Catches himself after almost offending Edie and adjusts his behavior to be more respectful and careful around her.
Invites Edie impulsively to the roof to see his pigeons, showing confidence and openness.
Not wanting to let go of Edie, following her, and asking if he will see her again, showing vulnerability and sincerity
Responds apologetically to Mrs. Collins when told to leave Edie alone, indicating respect and conciliatory behavior
Argues he can at least look at Edie because it's a free country, showing a defensive and somewhat confrontational tone
Does not effectively express his feelings; seems bewildered and confused when speaking to Edie, unable to clearly state his intentions or desires.
Attempts to follow and continue the conversation with Edie despite rejection, showing some persistence and social engagement.
Responds apologetically and keeps calm when confronted by Mrs. Collins, avoiding escalation.
Fails to assert himself confidently in the face of Mrs. Collins' insult, accepting the limitation imposed on him without challenge.
Has a look in his eyes that suggests vulnerability or depth, despite trying to act tough.
Appears as 'the kid brother' of a corrupt figure, described harshly as a 'bum' and a 'butcher' in a camel hair coat.
Is shown to have some kindness or interest in Edie, wanting to see her again.
Is described by Pop as a 'bum' and a controlled fighter, not independent or skilled in leadership.
Tries to act tough and has a noticeable look in his eyes as observed by Edie.
Is referenced as a corner saloon hoodlum by Pop, implying a rough reputation.
Edie says she'd walk home with a dozen Terry Malloys if they could help her, indicating loyalty and willingness to support.
Is described as a former fighter who still reacts when the bell rings, implying some remaining skill and readiness.
Referred to as a 'corner saloon hoodlum' and associated with negative influences, indicating a lack of respected competence or direction.
Manages his pigeons skillfully, uses a long pole to keep them circling and ensures they have enough exercise and water.
Shows familiarity and pride by indicating he started the Golden Warriors and was their first Supreme Commander.
Stops to admire Edie as she approaches, briefly distracted from his task.
Feeds Joey's pigeons in the morning without being asked.
Shows genuine interest in pigeons and explains their behavior sincerely.
Engages Edie in a friendly and proud manner about the pigeons.
Demonstrates knowledge and care for pigeons, feeds them, and explains their behavior thoughtfully.
Shows pride and confidence in his lead pigeon, indicates understanding of natural hierarchy among pigeons.
Engages in light boxing practice, showing some physical skill but not in a very serious or confident way.
Invites Edie to have a beer with him in a quiet saloon with a special ladies' entrance, showing consideration and friendliness.
Glances at Edie with a mischievous wink at the bartender, establishing a warm, friendly atmosphere.
Knows a quiet saloon with a special entrance for ladies and confidently leads Edie there.
Uses a mischievous wink to engage the bartender, showing social ease and awareness.
Guides Edie to a small table without awkwardness.
Orders drinks confidently, including two for chasers, adapting to Edie's unfamiliarity with drinks.
Watches Edie with amusement and tries to encourage her to enjoy the drink, showing playful friendliness.
Grins at Edie and engages in lighthearted conversation, demonstrating good-natured and sincere behavior.
Admits to taking dives in boxing with some shame, showing a degree of honesty and vulnerability.
Draws an invisible square to mock or criticize Edie by calling her 'Miss Four Corners,' suggesting a cool or teasing attitude that may lack warmth.
Swaggers confidently while teaching Edie how to drink and jokes around, showing social ease and confidence.
Admits he had to take a few dives in boxing and didn't stay in shape, showing some past failures and compromised integrity.
Shows ability to engage and amuse Edie with charm and wit, demonstrating social skillfulness.
Draws an invisible square to explain a concept, indicating some attempt at clever communication, though Edie is mystified.
Explains his rough life experience and straightforward philosophy, showing self-awareness and realism about his situation.
Dismisses Edie’s idealism and kindness as ‘drool’ and shows defensiveness when confronted, indicating emotional insecurity and limited interpersonal tact.
Recognizes consequences and tries to avoid danger ('I'm not lookin' to get crucified. I'm lookin' to stay in one piece').
Shifts conversation abruptly and uses insults ('What a fruitcake you are!') rather than engaging thoughtfully.
Attempts to justify his compromises and behavior with a resigned, street-smart attitude, showing awareness of his environment's rules.
Hesitates and avoids direct confrontation about serious matters, such as mentioning Joey by name, indicating emotional or mental blockage.
Displays bravado and tries to regain control of the conversation when challenged, showing some confidence.
Shows signs of defensive and troubled emotions, reflecting uncertainty and lack of conviction.
Feels immediate desire to help Edie when she cries out for help.
Turns back to Edie with a helpless gesture, expresses regret but says he can't help due to loyalty and fear.
Follows Edie out of the bar, magnetized by her presence despite earlier refusal to help.
Asks Edie if she is angry at him, showing concern for her feelings.
Says he has his whole life to drink, implying patience and a gentle refusal to hurry.
Feels torn between helping Edie and his loyalty to his brother and the mob; shows hesitation and admits he can't help her.
Responds to Edie's request with honesty and openness about his limitations.
Decides to follow Edie out despite initial hesitation, showing willingness to engage.
Gently asks Edie why she is crying, showing concern for her feelings.
Takes Edie's hand to walk her home the shortest way, showing care and consideration.
Encourages Edie to enjoy the music and dance, helping her to relax and feel joyful.
Pulls Edie to dance with him before she realizes, showing a playful and friendly side despite the impulsiveness.
Comforts Edie gently and confidently leads her through the crowd, taking initiative to lighten her mood by dancing with her and skillfully matching steps.
Draws Edie to him and dances closely, shares a kiss, showing affection and tenderness.
Puts his hand on Edie's arm to keep her close and protect her from danger, urging her to stay out of trouble.
Interrupts a romantic moment to take responsibility and promise to come back later, showing consideration for Edie.
Takes time to dance and share a tender moment with Edie, showing sensitivity and emotional awareness.
Responds to an urgent call from the boss but chooses to take Edie home first, balancing personal and professional demands.
For Edie's benefit, promises to come over when ready, showing some social tact and consideration.
Warns Edie to stay out of dangerous matters impulsively, showing awareness of risks but also a reactive rather than strategic approach.
Tries to protect Edie by warning her to stay out of danger, showing some caution and awareness.
Struggles to articulate his feelings clearly, apologizes as if it were a weakness, indicating insecurity and lack of confidence.
Considers fleeing when served a subpoena but is physically restrained, showing reactive rather than strategic behavior.
Refuses to testify and claims ignorance, maintaining a defensive stance but not demonstrating skill in handling the legal situation.
Refuses to cooperate with the police, insists 'I won't eat cheese for no cops,' showing loyalty to his own code but avoiding truth.
Avoids answering Edie's direct questions about Johnny Friendly and his brother's involvement in Joey's death, showing silence and inability to confront truth.
Despite Edie's anger and accusations, he pleads 'Don't say that, Edie, don't...' indicating sensitivity and care for her feelings.
Tells Edie to stop worrying about the truth and to look out for herself, deflecting responsibility and shirking honesty.
Expresses internal agony and pain after Edie leaves, showing emotional depth and sincere conflict.
Refuses to cooperate with the authorities, avoids telling the truth about Johnny Friendly and his brother Charley despite knowing it is important.
Shows emotional distress and confusion when confronted with the subpoena and the truth, indicating internal conflict and lack of resolve.
Attempts to protect Edie from harm by discouraging her from worrying about the truth, showing a misguided but protective intent.
Attempts to explain the church meeting to Johnny and tries to downplay any problems, seeking support from Charley.
Responds lamely and submissively to Johnny's mocking and intimidation.
Does not stand up to Johnny’s harsh tone and intimidation; looks to Charley for help.
Turns to Charley for help when confronted by Johnny Friendly, speaks lamely and tries to downplay the seriousness of the meeting.
Attempts to deflect Johnny's accusations by claiming nothing happened at the church meeting and tries to minimize the threat.
Appears surprised and somewhat confused when Johnny mocks his intelligence and questions his reliability.
Attempts to speak up for Nolan, saying 'Now just a minute, I—'
Is physically disciplined by Johnny through cheek twisting, but does not retaliate or respond aggressively
Looks after the car alone, feeling wounded yet silently enduring the treatment
Stands alone, feeling wounded and scowling after being roughly treated by Johnny and demoted, showing he is subdued and lacks control in the situation.
Attempts to speak up ('Now just a minute, I—') but is cut off and overridden by stronger personalities, indicating a lack of assertiveness or influence in critical moments.
Looks over at Nolan tensely while others laugh and celebrate with whiskey
Works grimly and anxiously instead of joining the cheerful mood
Works grimly and anxiously on the ship's hatch, despite the carefree behavior of others around him.
Looks tensely at Nolan and up out of the hatch, indicating awareness and possible concern about surroundings.
Turns and approaches Nolan nervously, tries to speak with him despite tension.
Displays misery when Nolan responds suspiciously, indicating openness and sincerity.
Approaches Nolan nervously and attempts to talk to him, showing hesitation and lack of confidence.
Tries to warn and pull Nolan out of danger when the cargo net is about to fall
Remains silent and does not join in the laughter at Big Mac's expense
Tries to pull Nolan back from the falling cargo net, reacting quickly to danger.
Watches the men's laughter and danger with cold sweat and stiff fear, showing hesitation and fear.
Remains in the same position, too stunned or passive to act after Kayo Nolan's injury and death.
Stands quietly, listens intently to Father's words about justice and conscience
Threatens Sonny for disrespecting Father Barry
Encourages Sonny to let Father Barry finish speaking despite Sonny's protests
Looks embarrassed after standing up for Father Barry, but maintains the stance
Threatening Sonny to stop his disruptive behavior and allowing Father Barry to speak despite potential danger.
Appears embarrassed after standing up for Father Barry and Edie notices his approval.
Throws a punch to stop Sonny from throwing a rotten banana at Father Barry, showing protection and support for the Father.
Is moved by Father Barry’s challenge and stands up to the corrupt mob influence despite risk.
Throws a punch that neatly flattens Sonny, standing up physically and symbolically against intimidation.
Is increasingly moved by Father Barry's challenge, indicating internal conflict but also emerging resolve.
Throws a short hard right that neatly flattens Sonny, showing physical skill and control.
Barely glances at Edie when she moves closer, then continues listening to Father Barry, indicating focus and self-control.
Turns away from Edie despite strong emotional impulse to go to her, showing restraint and consideration.
Is observed silently struggling with difficult feelings, indicating emotional sincerity and inner conflict.
Turns away slowly from Edie despite strong mutual feelings, demonstrating emotional restraint in a difficult personal moment.
Quietly contemplates his troubled thoughts while observing pigeons alone at night, showing introspection but also possible indecisiveness.
Accepts a coat from Edie gently and shows some vulnerability in his speech to her.
Draws close to Edie, expresses unfamiliar emotion, kisses her with release and relief.
Seeks confession and help from Father Barry, admits having 'blood on his hands' and shows anguish.
Clasps Father Barry's arms violently to gain attention, shows desperation.
Father Barry abruptly closes the confessional shutter when Terry tries to confess.
Expresses tenderness and vulnerability in front of Edie, showing emotional openness but lacks control and confidence in communication.
Attempts to confess to Father Barry, blurting out his guilt anxiously but fails to complete confession and is rejected.
Clutches Father Barry violently trying to get support, showing desperation but poor social tact and lack of composure.
Desperately tries to confess to Father Barry, admits guilt for setting up Joey Doyle, and struggles to be sincere with Edie.
Pursues Father Barry insistently to confess his guilt about setting up Joey Doyle, showing determination and a desire to make things right.
Struggles to fully articulate his feelings and explain his actions (e.g., stuck in his throat), indicating some emotional difficulty and lack of clear communication.
Expresses love and fear of losing Edie, showing vulnerability and sincerity.
Shows internal conflict about testifying against his brother and Johnny Friendly, indicating loyalty and emotional struggle.
Admits to not realizing he had a conscience before meeting Father Barry and Edie, demonstrating openness and potential for growth.
Waits passively for Father Barry to provide guidance or support rather than taking decisive action himself.
Reluctantly goes to Edie to tell her what he did to Joey, showing openness and honesty despite fear.
Tells Edie about his wrongdoing against Joey, indicating a desire to confess and seek forgiveness.
Reluctantly decides to confront Edie and attempt to confess what he did to Joey after Father Barry urges him to take responsibility.
Appears trembling and almost inarticulate, struggling to express himself clearly and confidently.
Despite nervousness and external interruption, he persists in trying to communicate an important truth to Edie.
His hesitation and emotional turmoil temporarily prevent him from fully asserting himself, causing a delay in clear communication.
Expresses desperation and anguish to Edie, showing vulnerability and desire for connection.
Calls out to Edie desperately after she turns away, indicating sincere concern and remorse.
Teases Jimmy about informing on someone but then reassures him of loyalty, calling him a good kid and emphasizing sticking together.
Expresses confusion and desperation openly, admits 'I don't know what to do' to Edie.
Attempts to influence Jimmy Conners to protect him and maintain loyalty among their group.
Engages in hesitant and unclear communication about the situation with the Commission investigator.
Remembers past leadership as a Golden Warrior and leverages that status to bond and seek support.
Engages in casual conversation and shares personal past fighting experience, showing willingness to open up.
Becomes sullen and suspicious when discussing sensitive topics, indicating guardedness and mistrust.
Shrugs off Glover's hopeful comment about telling the waterfront story, showing indifference or lack of enthusiasm.
Expresses disappointment and betrayal about being sold out by his own people, shows a moment of hesitation to reveal sensitive information.
Insulted when corrected about his boxing style, insists sincerely on his precision and skill.
Offers to walk along with Glover, showing friendliness and willingness to connect.
Describes his boxing style with confidence and knowledge, correcting Glover about his technique
Catches himself before revealing damaging information about others, showing hesitation or fear
Defends his brother Charley by calling him a good kid and expressing concern over his confused state.
Shows hesitation and nervousness about the plan to control his brother, indicating some internal conflict.
Not present or acting in this excerpt; no indication of competence or incompetence.
Expresses gladness that Charley stopped by and attempts friendly conversation.
Faltering when mentioning 'blood is thicker than water,' indicating some sincerity and internal conflict.
Speaks good-naturedly to Charley despite tense circumstances.
Replies sullenly and noncommittally about subpoena, showing guardedness and withholding information.
Initiates a conversation with Charley to discuss important matters, showing willingness to engage and take initiative.
Faltering while trying to recall a proverb, indicating slight hesitation or insecurity.
Accepts Charley's chosen route with good-natured humor, showing flexibility and social ease.
Responds noncommittally and sullenly to mention of subpoena, indicating possible reluctance or evasiveness.
Shows interest and asks questions about the boss loader job, indicating some awareness of opportunity.
Expresses uncertainty and indecision about testifying and his future, struggling with conscience and loyalties.
Acknowledges he wants a steady job and money but lacks clear ambition or a proactive plan.
Rejects Charley's derogatory insult about the ex-tanker, showing some defense and sensitivity.
Avoids violent confrontation despite Charley pulling a pistol on him, gently guiding the gun down.
Expresses uncertainty and inner conflict about testifying, indicating hesitation but no outright betrayal or coldness.
Shows vulnerability admitting 'I could have been better,' indicating self-awareness and sincerity.
Expresses deep emotional pain and betrayal towards Charley, appealing to their past brotherly bond.
Shows bitterness and self-pity, blaming others for his failures and perceived lost potential.
Remembers and clearly articulates his past boxing skills and potential, identifies missed opportunities with some insight.
Accuses Charley and others with emotional outburst, shows frustration but lacks constructive direction or solution.
Shows self-awareness about his current status and the consequences of past manipulation.
Jumps out of the cab and leaps onto the back of a moving bus to escape quickly.
Pounds on Edie's door persistently despite her refusal to let him in and breaks the door open.
Expresses pain and conflicted emotions about hurting both Charley and Edie, showing sincerity and vulnerability.
Pleading to Edie to believe him and wanting to be with her, showing earnestness and a desire for connection.
Pounds desperately on Edie's door and breaks in uninvited while wild-eyed, showing emotional impulsiveness and lack of control.
Expresses a deep emotional conflict about his loyalties and struggles to reconcile his feelings, indicating internal confusion but self-awareness.
Expresses anguish and confusion about his conscience, showing openness and vulnerability.
Tightly grips and breaks a glass in frustration, injuring himself unintentionally.
Seeks affection and reassurance from Edie by asking her to love him.
Gropes for Edie and embraces her despite her conflicted and resistant response.
Pounds his fist on the bed and squeezes a glass in distress, breaking it and injuring his hand unintentionally.
Expresses confusion and uncertainty aloud about what to do regarding his conscience.
Seeks emotional connection and support from Edie despite her resistance and conflict.
Responds to being called by peers outside with curiosity and interest (hears about his brother Charley).
Decides to go see Charley when called, despite Edie's pleading for him not to go.
Drops beside Charley's dead body and expresses grief, calling killers 'scummy, good-for-nuthin'' butchers.
Protects Edie by pulling her down behind him when danger approaches.
Tenderly straightens Charley's twisted arm.
Shows fury and sorrow but does not flee or give up, showing determination to act.
Asks Edie not to follow him and to call the Father to take care of his brother, showing concern for family.
Driven by rage, breaks the pawn shop glass and injures himself to get a gun for revenge.
Does not heed Edie's advice to go home and give up, acts impulsively in anger.
Determines to take violent revenge for his brother by arming himself despite physical pain and obstacles, showing determination and resourcefulness.
Acts impulsively in a rage, breaks into a pawn shop window, and puts himself at risk, possibly compromising his safety and caution.
Flings Edie away violently despite her sobbing and pleading.
Goes into the bar tense and suspicious, demanding whiskey and refusing advice or friendly concern.
He goes on alert, ready to confront an incoming threat, showing protective vigilance.
Ignores Father Barry’s plea to surrender the gun and responds with hostility ('Mind your own business,' 'You go to hell'), showing defiance and lack of respect.
Reaches for his gun quickly when hearing footsteps, showing alertness and readiness in a tense situation.
Keeps control despite a bleeding shoulder, prioritizing the situation over his injury.
Grows defensive and dismissive toward Father Barry, refusing to hand over the gun and responding with hostility.
Maintains a hardened demeanor when faced with authority, possibly showing emotional self-control but also a lack of strategic cooperation.
Charges Father Barry aggressively despite being weakened and injured, showing impulsiveness and lack of control.
Takes the gun back from Father Barry self-consciously, indicating indecision and lack of confident assertiveness.
Hears and seems affected by Father Barry's reasoned argument about fighting in the courtroom and using truth as a weapon, showing some openness to strategic thinking.
Throws his gun defiantly into the face of Johnny Friendly's picture, indicating a stand against corruption.
Looks around defiantly at tense gunmen but chooses to leave peacefully with Father Barry and the group.
Throws his revolver into the face of the picture defiantly, signaling a turning point and standing up to Johnny Friendly and his cronies.
Holds the gun self-consciously before throwing it, indicating some hesitation and lack of confidence initially.
Walks slowly into the courtroom to testify in front of the Waterfront Crime Commission, showing deliberate courage but uncertain confidence.
Takes the oath seriously and commits to telling the truth firmly in court.
Takes the stand to testify truthfully under oath, showing firm commitment to telling the truth.
Answers counsel's questions directly and clearly, showing clear understanding of situation and personal involvement.
Testifies truthfully in court against Joey Doyle and waterfront crime, exposing corruption.
Physically reacts instinctively and fights Johnny Friendly after being insulted and spat on in court.
Allows guards to separate him and does not escalate violence further.
Greets old friends Chick and Jackie, though they look at him coldly and turn away.
Irritably tells his police bodyguards to stop trailing him so closely.
Refuses Edie's offered coffee moodily, expressing a sense of isolation and sadness.
Acknowledges that his friends won't talk to him, showing vulnerability.
Terry manages to get his police bodyguards to understand his discomfort and subtly signals them to ease off, showing some social tact and situational control.
Terry feels uncomfortable and unhappy as his old friends treat him coldly and he appears emotionally drained, suggesting difficulty coping effectively with social alienation and personal conflict.
Calls out to Jimmy in a halfhearted, worried manner, shows concern for friends despite their silence.
Reacting brokenly and emotionally to the killing of his pigeons, showing deep attachment and sensitivity.
Does not respond with anger or aggression to the dead pigeon thrown at him, showing restraint and vulnerability.
Looks for support from friends and Jimmy but receives silence and hostility; responds with defeat and sorrow.
Realizes the gravity of the situation when he finds his pigeons dead and seems deeply affected; takes immediate action to check on them and respond.
Appears distracted and unresponsive to Edie's practical advice about safety and self-care.
Sits silently and does not respond to Edie's pleas to avoid the waterfront and change his life.
Handles the cargo hook with pent-up feeling, showing internal struggle and determination.
Disregards Edie's concerns and warnings about Johnny Friendly, demonstrating stubbornness.
Sits silently and contemplates the cargo hook, showing pent-up, mounting determination despite Edie's protests.
Refuses to verbally engage or respond to Edie's reasoning and advice, showing stubbornness and lack of open communication.
Takes Joey's windbreaker and wears it as a symbol of change and dignity, grins at Edie with new confidence.
Declares he is going down to the dock to get his rights, not to shoot anyone, showing restraint and sincerity.
Approaches the shape-up defiantly and faces Big Mac directly, despite the others instinctively moving away from him.
Brazenly challenges Big Mac by pointing out a man short for the last gang, showing boldness but potentially antagonistic behavior.
Puts on Joey's windbreaker deliberately and goes to the dock with a new sense of dignity and quiet resolve, declaring he is no longer a bum and will fight for his rights.
Walks into the shape-up confidently despite hostility, stands defiantly with hands in pockets and looks Big Mac in the eyes, challenging the system brazenly.
Is ignored and passed over by Big Mac deliberately during the hiring process, left standing alone as others are chosen before him.
Stands alone, brazenly calls out that they are a man short for the gang.
Looks around at others who avoid his gaze and feel guilty for passivity.
His fury grows but does not lash out; instead, he shows a contemplative and trembling response.
Turns and starts walking resolutely toward Johnny's headquarters, indicating a willingness to confront or take action.
Walks resolutely toward Johnny Friendly to confront him despite danger.
Shouts to get Johnny Friendly’s attention, trying to engage him.
Tries to talk to Johnny calmly and somewhat respectfully despite hostility.
Turns and starts walking slowly, resolutely down the gangplank toward Johnny's headquarters despite knowing the danger.
Shouts provocatively at Johnny Friendly outside his office, initiating a confrontation without apparent backup or clear plan.
Continues to advance and steam himself up as Johnny tries to dismiss him, showing determination but possibly impulsiveness.
Speaks defiantly and articulately against corrupt figures, expressing clarity and conviction in his stance.
Acknowledges his past complicity and their consequences, showing self-awareness and a shift in allegiance.
Engages in a violent physical fight with Johnny, skillfully matching him blow for blow, demonstrating physical capability and courage.
His defiant speech and fight provoke the attention of other longshoremen, indicating leadership potential and confidence.
Fights fiercely against several goons and manages to beat Johnny to the deck despite being outnumbered.
Continues fighting desperately but ultimately gets overwhelmed, beaten to a bloody, senseless state.
Shows physical bravery and resilience in combat under difficult conditions.
Fails to defeat or escape from the gang, resulting in severe injury and unconsciousness.
Terry is physically incapacitated and unable to work; others reference their reliance on him to take action
Is gravely injured, barely conscious, unable to walk or work, causing a standstill among longshoremen.
Despite severe wounds and pain, struggles to get on his feet and continues forward to face the crowd, showing determination and courage.
Looks around unseeingly and appears dazed, indicating vulnerability and openness.
Despite being badly wounded and dazed, makes a determined effort to get on his feet and walk up the ramp, continuing a symbolic act of defiance.
Initially confused and uncomprehending as he tries to stand, showing physical and mental weakness.
Leads the longshoremen bravely into the pier despite threats, showing courage and inspiring others.
Moves forward driven by Father Barry's will, displaying commitment to a cause larger than himself.
Steadies himself after stumbling and moves forward with determination despite pain and uncertainty.
Faces the Stevedore confidently, signaling readiness to proceed.
Leads hundreds of longshoremen into the pier, inspiring them to follow him despite threats from Johnny Friendly.
